description:
This contract demonstrates a simple Merkle tree leaf replacement within a covenant. Leaves can be used to maintain any kind of state that a covenant must manage internally like sealed ballots (e.g. shareholder votes), deposit receipts (e.g. for issuing refunds), an order book, etc.

This demonstration uses a 3-level Merkle tree for which each leaf has been initialized to OP_0:
 
                    rt
                 /      \
             z0           z1
            /  \         /  \
          y0    y1     y2    y3
          /\    /\     /\     /\
        x0 x1  x2 x3  x4 x5  x6 x7
        |  |   |  |   |  |   |  |
        a0 a1  a2 a3  a4 a5  a6 a7

In this demo, both "before" and "after" Merkle trees are simultaneously built/validated for each tree level, optimizing contract size.

You can explore scripts on the left sidebar:

- See the "Replace Empty Leaf" script for a full demo.
- See the "Left Sibling" and "Right Sibling" scripts for unit tests of a single tree level.

Note: Merkle trees are typically less efficient for state management than token commitments. Before choosing a Merkle tree, verify that the intended use case cannot be served by placing state in token commitments issued either to certain participants or to covenants designed for this purpose.
name: Experimenting with Contract State Merkle Trees

replace_empty_leaf.name: Replace Empty Leaf
replace_empty_leaf.script:
/**
 * This spending path proves that a5 has been properly replaced
 * with a new leaf value. (See description in locking script.)
 * 
 * Spender must provide:
 * 1) The new leaf value.
 * 2) The path from the replaced leaf to the root node
 *    with the opposite node at each level.
 * 
 * The value of the current root node is already part
 * of the contract, and the new root node will also be
 * computed by the contract (verifying that the respective 
 * transaction output is correct).
 * 
 * Proving: a5
 * Siblings required for proof: rt, z0, y3, x4
 **/

<node_z0>
<0> // sibling (z0) is left
<node_y3>
<1> // sibling (y3) is right
<node_x4>
<0> // sibling (x4) is left

<0> // current leaf value
<node_a5_filled> // new leaf value

verify_leaf_replacement.name: Verify Leaf Replacement
verify_leaf_replacement.script:
/**
 * This contract demonstrates a simple merkle tree leaf
 * replacement within a covenant. Leaves can be used to
 * maintain any kind of state that a covenant must manage
 * internally like sealed ballots (e.g. shareholder votes),
 * deposit receipts (e.g. for issuing refunds), an 
 * orderbook, etc.
 * 
 * This demonstration uses a 3-level merkle tree for 
 * which each leaf has been initialized to OP_0:
 * 
 *                  rt
 *               /      \
 *           z0           z1
 *          /  \         /  \
 *        y0    y1     y2    y3
 *        /\    /\     /\     /\
 *      x0 x1  x2 x3  x4 x5  x6 x7
 *      |  |   |  |   |  |   |  |
 *      a0 a1  a2 a3  a4 a5  a6 a7
 */

/**
 * By placing the current merkle root at the beginning of the
 * contract, we simplify the steps required to later reconstruct
 * the next covenant output (using OP_ACTIVEBYTECODE).
 */
<node_rt_empty> // (covenant is created with an empty merkle root)
OP_TOALTSTACK

/**
 * Perform any necessary validation on each leaf:
 */
// E.g. replaced leaf must be this particular literal:
OP_DUP <0x00deadbeef> OP_EQUALVERIFY // verify leaf_after (a#)
OP_HASH256 // node_after (x#)
OP_SWAP
// E.g. replaced leaf must be empty:
OP_DUP <0> OP_EQUALVERIFY // verify leaf_before (a#)
OP_HASH256 // node_before (x#)

/**
 * Now we verify both merkle proofs at the same time:
 */
build_tree_level // level: x
build_tree_level // level: y
build_tree_level // level: z

/**
 * The stack now contains the expected "before" and "after"
 * merkle roots. (Before and after the leaf replacement.)
 * 
 * On top is the "before" merkle root â€“ it must match
 * the root pushed at the beginning of this contract.
 */

// Confirm proof began with covenant's current merkle root
OP_FROMALTSTACK OP_EQUALVERIFY 

/**
 * The final stack item is the "after" expected merkle root
 * for the next covenant UTXO. We use it to build the
 * expected UTXO bytecode and enforce the covenant:
 */
build_next_utxo_bytecode
<0> OP_OUTPUTBYTECODE // covenant must be at output index 0
OP_EQUALVERIFY

// Finally, we confirm the covenant's balance is maintained:
 OP_INPUTINDEX OP_UTXOVALUE
<0> OP_OUTPUTVALUE OP_EQUAL

node_rt_empty.name: node rt empty
node_rt_empty.script:
$(
    OP_0 tree_proof // rt, z0, y3, x4
    OP_DROP
    OP_DROP
    OP_DROP
)

node_z0.name: node z0
node_z0.script:
$(
    OP_0 tree_proof // rt, z0, y3, x4
    OP_DROP
    OP_DROP
    OP_NIP
)

node_y3.name: node y3
node_y3.script:
$(
    OP_0 tree_proof // rt, z0, y3, x4
    OP_DROP
    OP_NIP
    OP_NIP
)

node_x4.name: node x4
node_x4.script:
$(
    OP_0 tree_proof // rt, z0, y3, x4
    OP_NIP
    OP_NIP
    OP_NIP
)

node_rt_filled.name: node rt filled
node_rt_filled.script:
$(
    <node_a5_filled> tree_proof // rt, z0, y3, x4
    OP_DROP
    OP_DROP
    OP_DROP
)

tree_proof.name: Tree Proof (a5)
tree_proof.script:
/**
 * 3-level merkle tree, each leaf is OP_0
 * 
 *                  rt
 *               /      \
 *           z0           z1
 *          /  \         /  \
 *        y0    y1     y2    y3
 *        /\    /\     /\     /\
 *      x0 x1  x2 x3  x4 x5  x6 x7
 *      |  |   |  |   |  |   |  |
 *      a0 a1  a2 a3  a4 a5  a6 a7
 * 
 * Creating a proof for a5: rt, z0, y3, x4
 */

OP_HASH256 // x5
OP_TOALTSTACK

OP_0 OP_HASH256 OP_DUP OP_CAT OP_HASH256 // y0/y1/y3
OP_DUP OP_DUP OP_CAT OP_HASH256 // y3, z0
OP_SWAP // z0, y3

OP_FROMALTSTACK // z0, y3, x5

OP_0 // z0, y3, x5, a4
OP_HASH256 // z0, y3, x5, x4
OP_DUP OP_TOALTSTACK // save x4

OP_SWAP // z0, y3, x4, x5

OP_CAT OP_HASH256 // z0, y3, y2
OP_SWAP // z0, y2, y3

OP_DUP OP_TOALTSTACK // save y3

OP_CAT OP_HASH256 // z0, z1

OP_SWAP OP_DUP OP_TOALTSTACK // save z0
OP_SWAP // z0, z1

OP_CAT OP_HASH256 // rt

OP_FROMALTSTACK // rt, z0
OP_FROMALTSTACK // rt, z0, y3
OP_FROMALTSTACK // rt, z0, y3, x4

build_tree_level.name: Build Tree Level
build_tree_level.script:
/**
 *  Tree:
 *                  rt
 *               /      \
 *           z0           z1
 *          /  \         /  \
 *        y0    y1     y2    y3
 *        /\    /\     /\     /\
 *      x0 x1  x2 x3  x4 x5  x6 x7
 *      |  |   |  |   |  |   |  |
 *      a0 a1  a2 a3  a4 a5  a6 a7
 */

OP_ROT // sibling, node_after, node_before, sibling_is_a_right_node

OP_DUP OP_SIZE OP_EQUALVERIFY // malleability protection
OP_IF // sibling is a right node
OP_ROT OP_TUCK // node_after, sibling, node_before, sibling
OP_ELSE // sibling is a left node
<2> OP_PICK OP_SWAP // sibling, node_after, sibling, node_before
OP_ENDIF
OP_CAT OP_HASH256 // node_before
OP_TOALTSTACK
OP_CAT OP_HASH256 // node_after
OP_FROMALTSTACK // node_after, node_before

left_sibling.check:
<node_y3> OP_EQUALVERIFY
<$(<0> OP_HASH256 <node_a5_filled> OP_HASH256 OP_CAT OP_HASH256)> OP_EQUAL
left_sibling.name: Left Sibling
left_sibling.setup:
<node_x4> // sibling
<0> // x4 is a left sibling (of x5)
<$(<node_a5_filled> OP_HASH256)> // node_after (the replacing node)
<$(<0> OP_HASH256)> // node_before (the replaced node)

right_sibling.check:
<node_z0> OP_EQUALVERIFY
<$(
    <0> OP_HASH256 
    <node_a5_filled> OP_HASH256
    OP_CAT OP_HASH256 // y2
    <node_y3>
    OP_CAT OP_HASH256 // y3
)> // z1
OP_EQUAL
right_sibling.name: Right Sibling
right_sibling.setup:
<node_y3> // sibling
<1> // y3 is a right sibling (of y2)
<$( // y2 node_after (the replacing node)
    <0> OP_HASH256
    <node_a5_filled> OP_HASH256
    OP_CAT OP_HASH256
)> 
<$( // y2 node_before (the replaced node)
    <0> OP_HASH256
    <0> OP_HASH256
    OP_CAT OP_HASH256
)>

build_next_utxo_bytecode.name: Build Next UTXO Bytecode
build_next_utxo_bytecode.script:
/**
 * Given the expected merkle root, build the next covenant UTXO bytecode.
 */
<OP_HASH160 OP_PUSHBYTES_20> // first part of P2SH bytecode
<OP_PUSHBYTES_32> // encode push of new merkle tree root
OP_ROT // new merkle tree root
< OP_PUSHBYTES_32 node_rt_empty 0xc0dec0dec0de > // simulate "OP_ACTIVEBYTECODE"
<33> OP_SPLIT OP_NIP // remove old merkle tree root
OP_CAT OP_CAT // redeem bytecode
OP_HASH160 // redeem bytecode hash
<OP_EQUAL> // second part of P2SH bytecode
OP_CAT OP_CAT
